sections.title: Spot the Mental Shortcuts
sections.subtitle: Learn to recognize and neutralize the biases that distort financial choices

sections.title: Key Takeaways
items: Understand the science behind behavioral biases
Identify the six most common money-related biases
Build systems that keep emotions from steering the wheel

sections.title: Bias Is Normal
sections.content: Human brains rely on shortcuts to process complex information quickly. In investing and money management those shortcuts can lead to predictable errors. Knowing the pattern lets you catch it before it causes damage.

points.title: Confirmation Bias
points.description: Seeking data that matches the decision you've already made while ignoring contradiction.

points.title: Anchoring
points.description: Letting the first number you hear—like a stock's past high—set unrealistic expectations.

points.title: Herd Mentality
points.description: Copying what friends or the market is doing because it feels safer than standing apart.

points.title: Loss Aversion
points.description: Feeling losses about twice as strongly as gains, which can lead to panic selling.

points.title: Overconfidence
points.description: Believing you can outsmart the market, causing excessive risk-taking.

points.title: Present Bias
points.description: Prioritizing short-term pleasure even when it undermines long-term goals.

sections.title: Pause Point
sections.content: When emotions spike, slow down. Waiting 24 hours on major money decisions reduces bias-driven mistakes.

sections.title: Defense Strategies
sections.content: Create checklists for big financial moves, invite a neutral third party to review decisions, and set rules (like a rebalancing schedule) that reduce the impact of emotional swings.

sections.title: Anti-Bias Toolkit
steps: Pick one recent financial decision and identify any bias that influenced it.
Design a short checklist that you will use before repeating that type of decision.
Set up a decision journal—log reasoning, feelings, and outcomes to reveal patterns over time.
Choose an accountability partner who can play devil's advocate on large purchases or investments.

sections.title: Use Pre-Commitment
sections.content: Automate contributions and diversify using broad index funds to minimize the number of decisions bias can affect.
